The catalytic hydrogenation of CO2 to formic acid (HCOOH) over silicon-metal (Si-M, M=Cr, Mn, Fe, Co) dual-atom catalysts (DACs) anchored on porous nitrogen-doped graphene was investigated through density functional theory (DFT) calculations. The structural stability, adsorption behavior of CO2 and H2, and reaction mechanisms were systematically analyzed. The results revealed that all Si-M DACs exhibit robust structural stability and efficient activation of CO2 and H2. CO2 adsorption exhibits three types of binding configurations (types I–III), and thereinto, the type III is the strongest with the binding energy of >1 eV for all the catalysts. The dissociative adsorption of H2 on all DACs experiences varying energy barriers (0.43–0.96 eV), forming Si–H and M–H bonds. Two distinct hydrogenation pathways were identified: (1) the CO2 adsorption route (including type II and type III), where CO2 chemisorption activates M-O frustrated Lewis pairs (FLPs) to heterolyze H2, and (2) the H2 dissociation route, leveraging Si-M dual sites for H2 cleavage followed by CO2 insertion. Among the four catalysts, SiCr@N₆G demonstrated the lowest energy barrier of 0.71 eV through the CO2 adsorption route (type III). This work provides theoretical insights into the remarkable synergistic effect between single-atom metal and Si sites in DACs on CO2 hydrogenation to HCOOH. Graphical abstract The Si-M dual-atom catalysts (M=Cr, Mn, Fe, Co) on N-doped graphene, where M-O frustrated Lewis pairs (FLPs) formed during CO2 adsorption enable efficient H2 heterolysis. Synergistic Si-M interactions enhance CO2 activation and H2 dissociation. The design underscores FLP-mediated synergy for CO₂ hydrogenation, offering insights for catalyst optimization. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Frustrated Lewis pairs (FLPs) Density Functional Theory (DFT) CO2 hydrogenation Dual-atom catalysts Synergistic effect 1 Introduction Over the past few decades, the release and accumulation of greenhouse gases, especially carbon dioxide (CO2), has been increasing [1]. The presence of high-level greenhouse gases in the atmosphere not only causes severe health problems but also brings about significant global climate changes. Therefore, there is an urgent demand to develop innovative technologies to capture CO2 and subsequently catalyze its conversion into valuable chemicals [2–4]. As one of the key chemicals, formic acid (HCOOH) has been widely used in industry [5,6], and the production of HCOOH from CO2 has garnered considerable attention. The majority of industrial formic acid production involves the reaction between methanol and CO under alkaline conditions, followed by the hydrolysis of methyl-formate [7,8]. Alternatively, considering the concept of atomic economy, a more efficient approach is to synthesize formic acid directly from carbon dioxide and hydrogen [8,9]. Nevertheless, high thermodynamic stability and chemical inertness of CO2 make this transformation difficult [7,10], and an economical, environmentally friendly and efficient catalyst is required to assist the production of HCOOH. In recent years, single-atom catalysts (SACs) have attracted considerable attention due to their high atomic utilization and excellent catalytic performance [11,12]. In particular, incorporating a single metal atom into a graphene sheet with the single vacancy defect can bring about significant hydrogenation activity of CO2 to HCOOH. Sirijaraensre et al. have demonstrated that Cu-embedded graphene sheets exhibit promising catalytic activity for the direct conversion of CO2 and H2 into formic acid with an energy barrier of 0.85 eV [9]. Esrafili et al. have shown that Pt-doped graphene displays relatively higher catalytic activity for the hydrogenation of CO2 compared to Ni-doped graphene [6]. Yodsin et al. have reported that Pt-decorated carbon nanocone (Pt/dCNC) is a potential catalyst for the conversion of CO2 into formic acid, with the rate-determining step being formic acid desorption corresponding to an energy barrier of 1.11 eV [13]. Sredojević et al. have conducted calculations on Ru and Cu-embedded graphene for CO2 hydrogenation and found that the path of dissociative adsorption of H2 is more favorable than the direct hydrogenation of CO2 [8]. Liang et al. have examined the impact of the coordination environment of the single-atom metal on CO2 hydrogenation efficiency on Sn-doped graphene, and their results demonstrated that relatively large N coordination numbers are not conducive to the reaction [14]. Ali et al. have shown that Pd is the most active site with an excellent catalytic activity toward CO2 hydrogenation among Cu, Pd, and Ru-supported graphenes [15]. Hence, the metal single-atom decorated graphene is an ideal potential candidate catalyst for CO2 hydrogenation. As an extension of SACs, dual-atom catalysts (DACs) possess higher loading amounts of catalytic atoms, resulting in improved accessibility to active sites [16,17]. Moreover, the catalytic activity of DACs is enhanced by the synergistic effect between adjacent active sites, while maintaining high atomic utilization efficiency, selectivity, and stability due to their atomically dispersed nature [18–20]. Although there are quite a few research reports on DACs for various catalytic applications, such as ORR [21], NRR [22], and CO2ER [23], the focus on DACs for CO2 hydrogenation remains limited. In a recent study by Ma et al., Sn−M (M = Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, Zn) dual-atom catalysts (DACs) were investigated for CO2 hydrogenation [24]. Their computational results suggested that these systems possess catalytic potential for CO2 reduction. However, it was also revealed that both CO2 and H2 were only physically adsorbed on the catalyst surfaces in their initial configurations. Such weak physisorption interactions are likely to limit the efficiency of the catalytic reaction, particularly under thermal conditions, where strong activation of reactants is essential to overcome kinetic barriers and drive the reaction forward. This observation highlights the need for designing more efficient dual-atom active centers that can chemically adsorb and activate both CO2 and H2. In this context, we turn our attention to silicon, a non-metal element with intriguing electronic characteristics. Our previous theoretical studies have shown that atomically dispersed Si sites anchored on N-doped graphene can effectively activate CO2 molecules due to the unique reactivity of the partially filled Si-pz orbitals [25]. Notably, the CO2 capture on the SiN4C4 sheet was observed during ab initio molecular dynamics (AIMD) simulations for 10 ps at room temperature, further confirming the stability and viability of the chemisorbed CO2 configuration under realistic conditions [26]. Building on this, we hypothesize that constructing Si−M dual-atom catalysts could yield a new class of DACs with enhanced cooperative effects and stronger binding interactions with both CO2 and H2. Herein, based on the electronic diversity, balanced adsorption strengths, and demonstrated catalytic activity in CO2 hydrogenation, we have chosen four transition metals (Cr, Mn, Fe, and Co) paired with silicon to engineer dual-atom sites on porous nitrogen-doped graphene, in order to identify more effective dual-atom catalytic centers for the hydrogenation of CO2. Notably, the Si−M sites in our system can function as solid-state frustrated Lewis pairs (FLPs). In such pairs, the silicon atom acts as a Lewis base, while the transition metal serves as a Lewis acid. Due to their spatial separation and electronic mismatch, FLPs can activate small molecules like H2 and CO2 through heterolytic cleavage. This concept was first developed in homogeneous catalysis and later extended to surfaces and solid materials [27,28]. Through the evaluation of CO2 adsorption energy and H2 dissociation energy at these silicon-metal (Si-M) diatomic sites, we have determined that these four Si-M dual-atom catalysts facilitate CO2 hydrogenation via two pathways: the CO2 adsorption route and the H2 dissociation route. Additionally, we have performed an in-depth examination of the mechanism underlying the CO2-to-HCOOH hydrogenation reaction catalyzed by these dual-atom catalysts. The present work is expected to ascertain the performance of silicon-metal dual-atom catalysts in CO2 hydrogenation, and provide a basis for rational design of metal-nonmetal dual-atom catalysts with the enhanced activity in formic acid production. 2 Computational methods The Vienna Ab initio Simulation Package (VASP) was utilized to carry out spin-unrestricted density-functional theory (DFT) calculations, employing the GGA-PBE exchange-correlation functional [29,30]. A plane-wave cutoff energy of 500 eV was applied, and a 5 × 6 × 1 Monkhorst-Pack k-point grid was used for Brillouin zone sampling. The structural optimization was performed with convergence criteria set to 10−5 eV for energy and 0.02 eV/Å for Hellmann-Feynman forces. To prevent interactions between adjacent layers, a vacuum spacing of 15 Å was established along the z-direction. The van der Waals (vdW) corrections were treated using the D3 method by Grimme [31]. The VASPKIT was employed to process the VASP output files [32]. The transition state (TS) for the elementary step was identified through the climbing image nudged elastic band (CI-NEB) and dimer methods [33,34]. To evaluate the structural stability of Si-M dual-atom catalysts, the formation energy (E f) of Si and metal are defined as (1) E f S i = E S i @ N 6 G − E S i − E N 6 G (2) E f Metal = E S i M @ N 6 G − E M − E S i @ N 6 G where E Si@N6G, E Si, E N6G, E SiM@N6G, and E M are the energies of Si-embedded N-doped graphene, a Si atom in its bulk structure, porous N-doped graphene, Si-M dual-atom catalyst and a metal atom in its bulk structure, respectively. The adsorption energy (E a) of CO2 is calculated as (3) E a = E C O 2 + S i M @ N 6 G − E C O 2 − E S i M @ N 6 G where E CO2+SiM@N6G and E CO2 are the energies of CO2-adsorbed SiM@N6G and an isolated CO2. The dissociative adsorption energy (E da) of H2 is calculated as (4) E da = E H 2 + S i M @ N 6 G − E H 2 − E S i M @ N 6 G where E H2+SiM@N6G and E H2 are the energies of H2-adsorbed SiM@N6G and an isolated H2. As shown in Equtaions 3 and 4, the more negative the predicted values are, the stronger the CO2 adsorption and H2 dissociative adsorption will be. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structural model and stability of catalysts Based on the structure of porous N-doped graphene, four dual-atom catalysts (DACs) named SiM@N6G (M = Cr, Mn, Fe, Co) were constructed. To evaluate the thermodynamic feasibility of forming heteronuclear Si−M dual-atom sites, we additionally calculated the binding energies (BE) of Si−M, Si−Si, and M − M configurations on the same N-doped graphene support (see Table S1). The results show that the energy differences among the three types of dual-atom motifs are generally small (within ∼1 eV), indicating that the Si−M structures are thermodynamically competitive with homonuclear alternatives. This suggests that the formation of Si−M active sites is synthetically achievable under appropriate conditions. As Fig. 1 shows, the atomically dispersed Si and metal sites in these four DACs are in coordination with four adjacent N atoms, and all the Si−N bond lengths are about 1.76 Å. However, the M − N bond lengths display a notable variation. In particular, the Cr−N bond is the longest, measuring 1.90 Å. This characteristic can be attributed to the significant protrusion of Cr atom from the plane of the porous N-doped graphene, resulting from its larger atomic radius compared to Mn, Fe, and Co. In contrast, the other three dual-atom catalysts maintain a more planar configuration, with relatively shorter M − N bond lengths. The formation of SiN4 and MN4 moieties result in a close proximity between Si and metal in the four catalysts, with distances of 2.61 Å for SiCr@N6G, 2.58 Å for SiMn@N6G, 2.56 Å for SiFe@N6G, and 2.55 Å for SiCo@N6G. This limited spatial separation facilitates the subsequent activation of CO2 and H2, which will be discussed in more detail below. The atoms that form the active sites of dual-atom catalysts (DACs) may spontaneously migrate and are involved in the surface reconstruction, a process that may lead to the deactivation of these catalysts. To address this concern, the formation energies of specific atoms, including Si, Cr, Mn, Fe, and Co have been calculated. As depicted in Fig. 2 , it is evident that the formation energies for Si, Cr, Mn, Fe, and Co are −4.4 eV, −2.5 eV, −3.0 eV, −2.7 eV, and −3.0 eV, respectively. The negative formation energies suggest a strong thermodynamic tendency for these atoms to disperse throughout the porous N-doped graphene framework. However, it is also important to consider the cohesive energies of the corresponding bulk metals, which are even more negative (−4.5 eV for Cr, –4.4 eV for Mn, –5.5 eV for Fe, and –5.6 eV for Co). This comparison indicates that, from a purely thermodynamic standpoint, metal aggregation into clusters would be energetically more favorable than atomic dispersion. Nonetheless, such a thermodynamic tendency can be counteracted by strong metal-substrate interactions and local coordination effects within the graphene matrix. In our systems, each metal atom is stabilized by coordination with four nitrogen atoms, forming robust Si−M dual-atom configurations that can kinetically hinder migration or aggregation. To further assess the thermal and kinetic stability of these configurations, we conducted extended ab initio molecular dynamics (AIMD) simulations at 600 K for 15 ps. As shown in Figure S1, the total energy remained stable throughout the simulation period, confirming the thermal robustness of the systems. Figure S2 displays the time evolution of Si−M bond distances and the atomic configurations before and after the simulation. The Si−M distances exhibit only minor fluctuations around their equilibrium values, and no signs of bond breakage or atom migration were observed. This indicates strong dynamic bonding between the dual atoms and surrounding nitrogen anchors, maintaining structural integrity under thermal stress. In addition, to directly evaluate the kinetic barrier for metal atom migration, we calculated the energy barrier for the Cr atom in the SiCr@N6G system to move from its original site to a neighboring coordination site. As shown in Figure S3, The migration barrier was found to be as high as 5.86 eV, suggesting that atomic diffusion is strongly suppressed under typical operating conditions. Taken together, these results demonstrate that although metal aggregation is thermodynamically favorable, the combination of strong metal-nitrogen coordination and substrate anchoring effects ensures excellent kinetic stabilization of the dual-atom catalysts. The observed negative formation energies, supported by extended AIMD simulations and high migration barriers, confirm that the SiM@DACs can maintain atomic dispersion under realistic reaction conditions. 3.2 Adsorption of species on si-m dual-atom catalysts To investigate the process of CO2 hydrogenation, including initial adsorption of CO2 and dissociative adsorption of H2, we firstly conducted an analysis on the interaction between SiM@N6G and both CO2 and H2. As illustrated in Fig. 3 , our results reveal that CO2 can be chemically adsorbed on the four DACs in three distinct modes. In the first mode (type I), Si and metal atoms bond with two O atoms of CO2, respectively. In the second mode (type II), Si and metal atoms bond with C and O atoms of CO2, respectively, and on the contrary, in the third mode (type III), Si bonds with O, while the metal atom bonds with C. For these CO2 adsorption configurations, the ∠OCO bond angles of CO2 vary from 120.4° to 128.4°, suggesting that CO2 is fully activated. In terms of the adsorption energy of CO2, all three modes are plausible, where the adsorption interaction in type III is much stronger than those in types I and II, with the binding energy of >1 eV. Specifically, the chemical adsorption of CO2 on SiCr@N₆G, SiMn@N₆G, SiFe@N₆G, and SiCo@N₆G in type III is a barrier-free process with the corresponding binding energies of −1.19 eV, −1.01 eV, −1.14 eV, −1.10 eV, respectively. In type I, the adsorption energies of CO2 on SiCr@N₆G, SiMn@N₆G, SiFe@N₆G, and SiCo@N₆G are −0.52 eV, −0.22 eV, −0.05 eV, 0.05 eV, respectively. In type II, the chemisorption energy of CO2 on SiCr@N6G is calculated to be −0.72 eV, indicating a thermodynamically favorable interaction, while the chemisorption energies of CO2 on SiMn@N6G, SiFe@N6G, and SiCo@N6G are calculated to be 0.01, 0.13, and 0.44 eV, respectively, suggesting that such adsorption processes are less favorable thermodynamically and need to be driven by the practical operating conditions such as increasing the partial pressure of CO2. Notably, both type II and type III configurations are capable of adsorbing H2, as shown in Fig. 3, and facilitating subsequent hydrogenation reactions. In contrast, the type I system fails to initiate CO2 hydrogenation reaction due to its inability to form stable H2 dissociation intermediates. Consequently, the subsequent discussion on CO2 hydrogenation is based on the adsorption configuration of type II and type III. Regarding the adsorption of H2, the results demonstrate that H2 can undergo dissociative adsorption on all the four DACs. As illustrated in Fig. 4 , the two dissociated hydrogen atoms can bond with both Si and metal atoms individually. Interestingly, across the four configurations involving dissociated H2, the Si−H bond lengths remain consistent at 1.49 Å, whereas the M − H bond length shows a decreasing trend as the atomic number of the metal increases. Generally, the reactivity of atomically dispersed Si is comparable across the four SiM@N6G. However, there are significant variations in the reactivity of the atomically dispersed metal sites, which provide the foundation for modulating the performance of the Si-M dual active sites. Notably, the dissociative adsorption energies (E da) of H2 on the four DACs are all negative, with values of −0.23 eV for SiCr@N6G, −0.63 eV for SiMn@N6G, −0.64 eV for SiFe@N6G, and −0.53 eV for SiCo@N6G. The results suggest that the dissociation of H2 is energetically favorable on these catalysts. Based on the dissociative configuration of H2, CO2 molecules can undergo physical adsorption on the surface (see Fig. 4) and subsequently react to produce HCOOH. The plausible mechanisms of this process will be elaborated in a subsequent section. Fig. 5 presents the projected density of states (PDOS) distribution for Si and Co in SiCo@N6G. As shown in Fig. 5a, the DOS of the Si-px and Si-py orbitals below the Fermi level is primarily concentrated in the low-energy region, which can be attributed to the strong bonding between Si and the four surrounding N atoms, leading to the formation of stable SiN4 moiety. Additionally, the Si-pz orbitals are notably spread out near the Fermi level, providing Si atoms with the dual capacity to donate and accept electrons. This unique electronic configuration significantly enhances the reactivity of Si atom, making it highly active site within the SiCo@N6G catalyst. Moreover, as depicted in Fig. 5b, the DOS for Co atom reveals a significant contribution from the Co-dz 2 and Co-dx 2 -y 2 orbitals near the Fermi level. The directional characteristics of the these orbitals enhance their interaction with other chemical species, thereby enhancing the reactivity of the Co atom. In summary, the Si and Co atoms in SiCo@N6G exhibit a significant number of electronic states near the Fermi level. This characteristic not only boosts their individual reactivity but also promotes synergistic interactions that are essential for the efficient activation of CO2 and dissociative adsorption of H2. Furthermore, this characteristic is not exclusive to SiCo@N6G, and similar trends are also observed in SiCr@N6G, SiMn@N6G and SiFe@N6G, as illustrated in Figure S4. Based on the aforementioned findings, it is suggested that two primary pathways, depending on the reactant feed sequence, might account for the hydrogenation of CO2 on the four Si-M dual-atom catalysts. One route involves the chemisorption of CO2 prior to H2 feeding, implemented through type II and type III configurations, while the other involves the predissociation adsorption of H2. A more detailed exploration of these mechanisms is presented in the following discussion. 3.3 Reaction mechanisms of CO2 hydrogenation on Si-m dual-atom catalysts The coexistence of CO2 adsorption and H2 dissociation on the four SiM@N6G catalysts enables two potential pathways for the hydrogenation of CO2 to form HCOOH. These pathways are referred to as the CO2 adsorption and H2 dissociation routes, respectively. In the CO2 adsorption route, CO2 is firstly adsorbed on the active site of SiM@N6G. This interaction is pivotal as it initiates a series of chemical transformations that lead to the production of HCOOH. Conversely, the H2 dissociation route involves the direct predissociation of H2 on SiM@N₆G, and then the adsorbed atomic hydrogen species interact with CO2 to produce HCOOH. Both mechanisms contribute to the overall CO2 hydrogenation process on SiM@N₆G. The relative importance of each pathway can be influenced by various factors, and a comprehensive understanding of these mechanisms would be conducive to the development of high-performance DACs toward CO2 hydrogenation. 3.3.1 The CO2 adsorption route In the CO2 adsorption route, CO2 is initially chemically adsorbed on the four DACs, leading to the formation of µ2–η2-CO2-chemisorbed configurations (type II and type III). 3.3.1.1 The type II As for the type II adsorption, the calculated energy barriers of CO2 adsorption on SiCr@N₆G, SiMn@N₆G, SiFe@N₆G, and SiCo@N₆G are 0.51 eV, 0.42 eV, 0.86 eV, and 0.73 eV, respectively. Although these values indicate that the chemisorption of CO2 is not barrierless, the barriers are moderate and fall within the range reported for effective heterogeneous catalysts. For example, based on kinetic estimates using the Arrhenius equation with a pre-exponential factor of 1013 s−1, the rate constant for the highest barrier (0.86 eV) remains above 6.90 × 103 s−1 at 473.15 K, confirming that CO2 adsorption is not rate-limiting at typical reaction temperatures. Fig. 6 shows the electron transfer following CO2 adsorption on the four DACs. One can see that each CO2 molecule acquires more than one electron. Specifically, these electrons are derived from three primary sources: Si, metal, and the substrate (the porous N-doped graphene framework). Generally, Si donates the least number of electrons, whereas the substrate contributes the most. This observation implies that Si acts as an electron transport intermediary during CO2 adsorption, facilitating the transfer of electrons from the electron-rich substrate to CO2. Additionally, metals also provide electrons, and the formation of M − O bonds can further activate CO2, thereby promoting its subsequent hydrogenation. Recent studies have highlighted the synthesis of metal-metal dual-atom catalysts and their substantial potential in catalytic applications [17,20,35]. Herein, we explore the distinctions between metal-metal (M-M) and silicon-metal (Si-M) dual-atom catalysts. Figure S5 depicts the typical configurations of the metal-metal dual-atom catalysts being studied. The differences in CO2 adsorption energy (type II) and H2 dissociation energy between M-M and Si-M dual-atom catalysts (ΔE = E M- M − E Si-M) are summarized in Figure S6. Our results indicate that, in comparison to Si-M dual-atom catalysts, M-M dual-atom catalysts exhibit higher CO2 adsorption and H2 dissociation energies. For instance, CO2 adsorption and H2 dissociation energies on CrCr@N₆G shows are 0.25 eV and 0.63 eV larger than those on SiCr@N₆G, respectively. These findings suggest that Si-M dual-atom catalysts are more conducive to the adsorption of CO2 and the dissociation of H2, underscoring the importance of dispersed Si atoms in enhancing the activation of these molecules. The above mentioned CO2 adsorption process is critical for generating metal-oxygen (M-O) frustrated Lewis acid-base pairs (FLPs) [36–38]. When CO2 is adsorbed on SiM@N6G, it interacts with the dual active sites of Si and metal, leading to the formation of Lewis acidic sites (Mδ+) and Lewis basic sites (Oδ−), thus creating M-O frustrated Lewis pairs (FLPs). To further verify the formation of M-O FLPs, Bader charge analysis was carried out on the optimized CO2 adsorption configurations. Specifically, for the SiCr@N6G system, the Cr atom carries a charge of +1.61 e, while the bonded oxygen atom bears a charge of –0.97 e. In SiMn@N6G, the Mn center is positively charged at +1.30 e, and the corresponding O atom reaches –1.04 e. For SiFe@N6G, the Fe atom and oxygen atom exhibit +1.11 e and –0.94 e, respectively. In the case of SiCo@N6G, the Co center carries a charge of +0.83 e, and the O atom is charged at –0.98 e. These charge distributions demonstrate the existence of localized electrostatic asymmetry between the two atoms, which is the essential feature of an FLP system. The presence of these M-O FLPs in such dual-atom catalysts fosters a unique chemical environment that promotes the heterolytic dissociation of H2. Upon interaction with the M − O bond, H2 becomes polarized due to the electric field generated by the M-O FLPs. As a result, the hydrogen molecule experiences heterolytic cleavage, with the hydride fragment (Hδ⁻) being attracted to the Lewis acidic metal site and the proton (Hδ⁺) being drawn to the Lewis basic oxygen site. This process yields a metal-hydride species (M-Hδ⁻) and a protonated oxygen species (OHδ⁺) on these DACs. The calculated energy barriers for the heterolysis of H2 by M-O FLPs on SiCr@N₆G, SiMn@N₆G, SiFe@N₆G, and SiCo@N₆G are 0.72 eV, 0.42 eV, 0.51 eV, and 0.19 eV, respectively. In the following step, electrostatic forces play a crucial role as the partially negatively charged hydrogen atom (Hδ−) in *MH interacts with the partially positively charged carbon atom (Cδ+) present in the *SiCOOH group. This interaction, driven by polarity, prompts a nucleophilic attack of Hδ− on the electrophilic Cδ+ site, thereby facilitating the formation of HCOOH. The reaction is marked by the transfer of Hδ− from *MH to *SiCOOH. The energy barriers for this process are 1.29 eV for SiCr@N6G, 1.11 eV for SiMn@N6G, 1.52 eV for SiFe@N6G, and 1.08 eV for SiCo@N6G, respectively. Fig. 7 depicts the full process of CO2 hydrogenation to HCOOH through the CO2 adsorption route (type II). Note that the energy profiles are plotted with respect to the total energy of the fully separated reactants (SiM@N6G + CO2 + H2), which is taken as the zero-energy reference. The values represent DFT total electronic energies without zero-point energy or entropy corrections, unless otherwise specified. As Fig. 7 shows, the mechanisms of CO2 hydrogenation on these four DACs share fundamental similarities, each exhibits unique energy barriers. Specifically, the stages of CO2 adsorption and the heterolytic cleavage of H2 are identified as relatively facile steps in the reaction sequence, implying that these initial interactions with the Si-M active sites present minimal energetic obstacles. The efficiency of these steps indicates that the Si-M dual sites effectively facilitate the binding and activation of both reactants. Consequently, the formation of HCOOH stands out as the rate-determining step (RDS) in the CO2 hydrogenation process across all four DACs. 3.3.1.2 The type III In the case of type III, the adsorption of CO2 on the four DACs is remarkably robust and highly favorable. During this initial adsorption process, the distal oxygen atom of the CO2 forms metal-oxygen frustrated Lewis pairs (M-O FLPs) with metal atoms on the surface, which play a crucial role in facilitating the subsequent dissociative adsorption of H2 molecules. However, the excessive stability of the CO2 adsorption configuration in type III presents a challenge, particularly since the dissociation of H2 on these M-O FLPs does not occur as readily as one might initially anticipate. Detailed calculations indicate that the energy barriers for H2 heterolysis on the M-O FLPs of SiCr@N6G, SiMn@N₆G, SiFe@N6G, and SiCo@N6G are 0.71, 1.40, 1.60 and 2.34 eV, respectively. Among these systems, the relatively low energy barrier required for H2 dissociation on SiCr@N6G is particularly noteworthy. This can be attributed to the unique structural arrangement of the Cr atom, which protrudes more prominently (by approximately 0.24 Å) from the catalyst surface compared to other metal atoms. Such geometric distortion directly modulates the electronic structure of the metal sites. As depicted in Figure S7, which illustrates the partial density of states (PDOS) when H2 physically adsorbs onto CO2-adsorbed DACs (Type III), the Cr atom possesses the highest d-band center at 0.09 eV, whereas the Co atom shows the lowest at −1.92 eV. Mn and Fe atoms exhibit intermediate d-band centers at −0.86 eV and −0.74 eV, respectively. The upward shift of the d-band center enhances the binding energy of the *SiOCOH-MH intermediate, aligning with the predicted lowest H2 dissociation barrier (0.71 eV) for SiCr@N6G. Consequently, it can be inferred that the protrusion of Cr atom significantly raises its energy level and enhances its ability to bond with hydrogen. Ultimately, the hydrogen atom on the metal-hydrogen (*MH) site attacks the carbon atom of the adsorbed CO2, leading to the formation of HCOOH. For this final step, the process is barrierless on SiFe@N6G and SiCo@N6G, indicating a relatively smooth reaction pathway. On the contrary, the transition state energy barriers on SiCr@N6G and SiMn@N₆G are 0.27 eV and 0.05 eV, respectively. Fig. 8 presents the reaction pathway for the entire CO2 hydrogenation process, starting from the adsorption configuration of type III. It is clear that the dissociation of H2 on CO2-adsorbed DACs is the rate-limiting step of the whole reaction, primarily due to the excessively strong adsorption of CO2 on the catalyst surface. However, the protrusion of the Cr atom from the surface elevates its energy level, effectively lowering the energy barrier for H2 dissociation. Consequently, for type III, SiCr@N6G demonstrates exceptional catalytic performance. 3.3.2 The H2 dissociation route Within the SiN4 structural motif, the central Si intriguingly retains a partially occupied Si-pz orbital, despite its carrying a positive charge. This unique electronic configuration bestows the Si atom with a dual character, rendering it both electrophilic and nucleophilic. Consequently, its reactivity and versatility in chemical interactions are significantly enhanced. Within the porous N-doped graphene framework, the Si-M dual active sites exhibit remarkable synergy: the M sites function as Lewis acid centers, while the Si sites serve as Lewis base centers. This arrangement is reminiscent of frustrated Lewis acid-base pairs, where the close spatial relationship and electronic complementarity between the acidic and basic sites enable highly efficient catalytic processes. Our results reveal that H2 can directly dissociate at the Si-M dual-atom sites, resulting in the formation of Si−H and M − H bonds. Notably, the energy barriers of H2 dissociation vary among different Si-M sites: SiCr@N6G, SiFe@N6G, and SiCo@N6G exhibit barriers of 0.43, 0.96 and 0.64 eV, respectively, whereas SiMn@N₆G presents a significantly higher barrier of 1.49 eV. Despite such high H2 dissociation barrier for SiMn@N6G, an interesting promoting mechanism is observed, which involves neighboring N atom and substantially facilitates the process. The H2 dissociation initiates at the Si−N unit, leading to the formation of an intermediate *SiHNH species with an energy barrier of 0.89 eV. Following this, the H atom in *NH migrates towards the Mn atom, overcoming a notably low energy barrier of 0.74 eV. Besides, this migration step is exothermic, thereby increasing its probability. Upon the formation of *SiH-MH, CO2 is smoothly incorporated into the *MH moiety, leading to the formation of *SiH-MOCHO. It is noteworthy that, in the hydrogenation step illustrated in Fig. 9 , the hydride species (*MH) consistently attacks the carbon atom of the CO2 moiety rather than the oxygen atoms. This regioselectivity can be rationalized by considering both electronic and structural factors. From an electronic perspective, the hydride species generated via H2 dissociation at the Si–M dual site is nucleophilic in nature, carrying a partial negative charge (Hδ⁻). Meanwhile, the carbon atom of CO2 bears a substantial partial positive charge, making it the most favorable electrophilic target. In contrast, the oxygen atoms possess lone pairs and typically hold partial negative charges, making them electrostatically incompatible with nucleophilic attack by Hδ⁻. Geometrically, attempts to model a hydride transfer to the oxygen site resulted in highly strained and unstable structures. Specifically, such configurations required the carbon atom to shift closer to the metal center to preserve coordination, which in turn forced the non-reacting oxygen atom into close contact with the catalyst surface. Consequently, both the charge distribution and steric constraints collectively render carbon-selective hydrogenation the most favorable and viable pathway in this system. The energy barriers for this CO2 insertion step are 0.50 eV for SiCr@N6G, 0.68 eV for SiMn@N6G, 1.01 eV for SiFe@N6G, and 1.26 eV for SiCo@N6G. Subsequently, the *OCHO group undergoes a pivotal rotational movement, positioning the O atom in close proximity to the H atom of the adjacent *SiH moiety. This rotation is a configuration change that is energetically favorable, being exothermic, which promotes its occurrence under appropriate conditions. In the final step, the H atom in the *SiH moiety executes an electrophilic attack on the O atom within the *OCHO group, resulting in the formation of HCOOH. The energy barriers for this concluding step also vary among the different DACs: 1.10 eV for SiCr@N₆G, 0.91 eV for SiMn@N₆G, 0.98 eV for SiFe@N₆G, and 0.87 eV for SiCo@N₆G. The detailed reaction mechanism through the H2 dissociation route is illustrated in Fig. 9. In summary, the SiM@N6G catalysts with the Si-M dual active sites demonstrate a complex but highly coordinated reaction activity pattern, which proceeds sequentially through the steps of H2 dissociation, CO2 insertion, and subsequent chemical transformations, ultimately leading to the formation of HCOOH. The specific energetics of these processes are significantly influenced by the choice of metal incorporated within the porous N-doped graphene framework, highlighting the tunability and potential for rational design of dual active sites for targeted catalytic applications. Table 1 provides an overview of the rate-determining steps and their corresponding energy barriers for the hydrogenation of CO2 to HCOOH on the four DACs. Under the CO2 adsorption route (type II), it is evident that all the four DACs share a common rate-determining step. Nevertheless, the energy barriers exhibit significant differences. Among them, SiCo@N6G demonstrates the lowest energy barrier at 1.08 eV, and the next SiMn@N6G has an energy barrier of 1.11 eV. Conversely, SiFe@N6G presents the highest energy barrier of 1.26 eV. In the type III CO2 adsorption pathway, the four catalysts also share the same rate-determining step, i.e., the dissociation of H2 on the CO2-adsorbed DACs. Notably, SiCr@N6G exhibits the lowest energy barrier of 0.71 eV, highlighting its superior performance in this process. The situation changes when the H2 dissociation route is considered. In this case, the formation of HCOOH is the rate-limiting step for SiCr@N6G and SiMn@N6G, whereas the insertion of CO2 into the reaction intermediate becomes the bottleneck for SiFe@N6G and SiCo@N6G. Notably, SiMn@N6G emerges as the most efficient catalyst in this route, with an impressively low energy barrier of 0.91 eV, indicating its enhanced catalytic performance. To gain deeper insight into pathway preference, we also compared the initial energy barriers of each route. While type III CO2 adsorption is barrierless for all catalysts due to strong chemisorption, the subsequent H2 dissociation step governs the overall kinetics and varies significantly. In the type II route, initial CO2 adsorption barriers differ modestly (0.42−0.86 eV), yet the RDS still controls the overall activity. Similarly, in the H2 dissociation route, initial barriers (0.43−0.96 eV) suggest thermodynamic feasibility, but the RDS remains the decisive factor. These observations reveal that although low initial barriers indicate pathway accessibility, they alone do not determine catalytic efficiency. Instead, the overall energy span, particularly the RDS barrier, defines the dominant reaction channel. Overall, the performance of the four Si-M dual-atom catalysts in promoting the conversion of CO2 to HCOOH may vary, and the catalytic behavior of each system strongly depends on the reaction pathway. Clearly, all four catalysts exhibit the capability to drive the CO2-to-HCOOH conversion, but the most favorable route differs depending on the metal species. Among them, the SiCr@N6G catalyst demonstrates the highest activity, with the lowest energy barrier of 0.71 eV identified along the CO2 adsorption pathway (type III). To further assess the thermodynamic feasibility of this dominant pathway, Gibbs free energy correction was applied to its rate-determining step. After accounting for zero-point energy and entropy contributions at 298.15 K, the energy barrier slightly increased to 0.83 eV. This result confirms that the reaction remains kinetically favorable under ambient conditions, and that the originally proposed mechanism remains valid after free energy correction. Given that the three examined pathways share similar elementary steps and transition-state structures, it is reasonable to expect that free energy corrections for other systems would follow similar trends. 4 Conclusion The present theoretical investigation provides a detailed analysis of the catalytic performance of Si-M (M = Cr, Mn, Fe, Co) dual-atom catalysts for the hydrogenation of CO2 to HCOOH. The Si-M dual-atom sites facilitate the creation of frustrated Lewis acid-base pairs (FLPs), which may aid in the activation of CO2 and the dissociative adsorption of H2. The present results indicate that both the pathways involving CO2 preadsorption and H2 predissociation are feasible for CO2 hydrogenation over Si-M DACs. The CO2 adsorption route involves FLP-mediated H2 heterolysis, with HCOOH formation as the rate-determining step in type II (SiCo@N₆G: 1.08 eV) and H2 dissociation on CO2-adsorbed DACs as the rate-determining step in type III (SiCr@N₆G: 0.71 eV). The H2 dissociation route involves CO2 insertion and HCOOH formation, with SiMn@N₆G achieving the lowest barrier (0.91 eV). The synergistic effect between Si and transition metals, particularly electron transfer and FLP formation, enhances catalytic efficiency. This work highlights the potential of Si-M dual-atom catalysts for efficient CO2 conversion and provides valuable guidance for designing advanced catalysts for sustainable chemical synthesis. coredata.dc:description: The catalytic hydrogenation of CO2 to formic acid (HCOOH) over silicon-metal (Si-M, M=Cr, Mn, Fe, Co) dual-atom catalysts (DACs) anchored on porous nitrogen-doped graphene was investigated through density functional theory (DFT) calculations. The structural stability, adsorption behavior of CO2 and H2, and reaction mechanisms were systematically analyzed. The results revealed that all Si-M DACs exhibit robust structural stability and efficient activation of CO2 and H2. CO2 adsorption exhibits three types of binding configurations (types I–III), and thereinto, the type III is the strongest with the binding energy of >1 eV for all the catalysts. The dissociative adsorption of H2 on all DACs experiences varying energy barriers (0.43–0.96 eV), forming Si–H and M–H bonds. Two distinct hydrogenation pathways were identified: (1) the CO2 adsorption route (including type II and type III), where CO2 chemisorption activates M-O frustrated Lewis pairs (FLPs) to heterolyze H2, and (2) the H2 dissociation route, leveraging Si-M dual sites for H2 cleavage followed by CO2 insertion. Among the four catalysts, SiCr@N₆G demonstrated the lowest energy barrier of 0.71 eV through the CO2 adsorption route (type III). This work provides theoretical insights into the remarkable synergistic effect between single-atom metal and Si sites in DACs on CO2 hydrogenation to HCOOH.
